posts.hook: That $85 steak didn't look expensive until you saw the $145 ribeye first.
posts.cta: What's the most expensive anchor you've seen used effectively?
posts.postBody:
That $85 steak didn't look expensive until you saw the $145 ribeye first.

Restaurants know something your rational brain refuses to accept. The first price you see isn't just information. It's an anchor, and it drags every subsequent judgment in its direction.

I watched this happen last month at a client dinner. The menu opened with a $145 dry-aged ribeye. Suddenly, the $85 filet felt reasonable. The $55 wine seemed like a bargain. None of us ordered the ribeye, but it did its job. It set the frame.

This is anchoring bias. Your Old Brain craves context, so it latches onto the first number it sees and uses it as a reference point for everything that follows. The steakhouse isn't manipulating you. It's working with your psychology.

In "The Divided Brain," I explore how this bias shapes far more than restaurant bills. Salary negotiations. Real estate listings. Software pricing tiers. The first number always wins.

What's the most expensive anchor you've seen used effectively?

#BehavioralPsychology #DecisionMaking #PricingStrategy #ConsumerBehavior #TheDividedBrain

posts.hook: Customers will forgive mistakes ‚Äî but they won't forgive unfairness.
posts.cta: Have you ever stuck with a brand ‚Äî not because it was perfect, but because it treated you fairly?
posts.postBody:
Customers will forgive mistakes ‚Äî but they won't forgive unfairness.

In The Divided Brain, I explain how deeply our Old Brain craves fairness. It isn't just cultural ‚Äî it's biological.

One of my favourite examples is a famous study with capuchin monkeys. Two monkeys were asked to perform the same task. One was rewarded with a cucumber slice, the other with a grape (the preferred treat). When the monkey getting the cucumber saw the other rewarded with a grape for the same work, it erupted in protest ‚Äî throwing the cucumber back at the researcher.

That same wiring drives human behaviour in business. You can have the best product features, the lowest prices, or the slickest pitch ‚Äî but if people sense unfair treatment (hidden fees, shifting terms, broken promises), trust evaporates.

On the other hand, when brands communicate fairness and transparency, they build loyalty that outlasts any feature list. Customers will overlook mistakes if they believe they've been treated fairly.

üëâ Fairness isn't "soft." It's a competitive advantage.

Have you ever stuck with a brand ‚Äî not because it was perfect, but because it treated you fairly?

posts.hook: Why do customers abandon their shopping carts? The Old Brain's Golden Rule is Simplicity.
posts.cta: Ready to align your brand with how the brain actually works?
posts.postBody:
üß† Why Simplicity Wins Every Time: The Old Brain's Golden Rule

Why do customers abandon their shopping carts? Why do complex presentations fail to stick? The answer lies in the oldest, bossiest part of our mind: the Old Brain.

Its golden rule is Simplicity.

The Old Brain is hard-coded to conserve energy and choose the path of least resistance. This isn't laziness ‚Äî it's an evolutionary survival mechanism designed to prioritize effort for real threats, not complicated checkout forms or confusing interfaces.

The moment your product, message, or process introduces friction, your customer's primal programming steers them away.

For leaders and brand-builders, this is a critical insight:

Simplify your message: The Old Brain prefers concise, digestible information. It needs a smooth runway.

Remove Friction: Streamline every touchpoint, from transparent pricing to intuitive design, so the large gear can turn effortlessly.

As Leonardo da Vinci said, "Simplicity is the ultimate sophistication." Align your brand with this primal urge, and you'll find the path to effortless conversion and lasting loyalty.

posts.hook: We are not thinking machines. We are feeling machines that think.
posts.cta: What was the last major purchase you made? Did you decide with your Old Brain or your New Brain?
posts.postBody:
"We are not thinking machines. We are feeling machines that think."

In my book, The Divided Brain, I break down this famous quote from neurologist Antonio Damasio using a simple metaphor: think of the brain as two interlocking gears.

The Old Brain (The Big Gear): Fast, emotional, survival-driven. It decides instantly.
The New Brain (The Small Gear): Slow, logical, analytical. It rationalizes the decision later.

Your customer's New Brain isn't the CEO. It's the Press Secretary.

Its job isn't to make the decision. Its job is to hold the press conference and explain why the decision the Old Brain already made was a "smart strategic move."

Be brutally honest with yourself and think about the last luxury item you bought. Did you really buy it because of the craftsmanship? No. You bought it because of how it made you feel (Status? Belonging? Joy?). Then you used the craftsmanship specs to explain the expense to your partner, friends, and anyone else who would listen.

This isn't a flaw. It's a feature. And yes, I have a Rolex.

If you lead your pitch with logic, you're talking to a brain that hasn't approved the budget yet.

Don't try to debate the Press Secretary. Win over the CEO.

What was the last major purchase you made? Did you decide with your Old Brain or your New Brain?

posts.hook: Your customers won't remember your data. They will remember your story.
posts.cta: Your customer is the Hero. You are the Mentor.
posts.postBody:
Your customers won't remember your data. They will remember your story.

In The Divided Brain, I break down why facts often bounce off the mind while stories stick. It comes down to the "gatekeeper."

Your customer's Old Brain is constantly scanning for information it can ignore to save energy. Bullet points? Ignore. Generic claims? Ignore. Complexity? Ignore.

Storytelling is the Trojan Horse.

It is the only communication tool that bypasses the Old Brain's defences and delivers your message directly to the decision-making center.

Why? Because a good story triggers a powerful neurochemical cocktail:

Dopamine (The Hook): Great stories create suspense and anticipation, keeping the Old Brain engaged.

Oxytocin (The Bond): When a narrative evokes empathy, the brain releases oxytocin ‚Äî the "trust molecule." It makes your brand feel human.

Endorphins and Serotonin (The Payoff): A satisfying conclusion creates a sense of well-being. If your product provides that resolution, your brand gets associated with that positive feeling.

The biggest mistake I see brands make is casting themselves as the Hero of the story. Your customer is the Hero. You are the Mentor.

Stop trying to "educate" your customers with facts. Start treating your marketing like a narrative.

When you sync the emotional rhythm of the Old Brain with the logical validation of the New Brain, you don't just get a sale. You get a believer.

posts.hook: Is Your Old Brain Making You Overpay? The Scarcity Trap.
posts.cta: Before you click Buy, pause and ask: genuine need, or manufactured fear of loss?
posts.postBody:
Is Your Old Brain Making You Overpay? The Scarcity Trap.

We all believe we're rational shoppers, but a flashing "Limited Stock!" or "Sale Ends Tonight!" banner works because it triggers the Scarcity Bias. Our ancient, emotional Old Brain is hardwired for survival, viewing scarcity as a threat to resources. It floors the gas pedal, triggering FOMO and overriding rational thought.

This impulse is so fast, the logical New Brain rarely gets a say.

To prevent an impulse buy, you must engage your New Brain and deploy its superpower: Metacognition. You have to shift gears manually. Before you click "Buy," pause for five seconds and ask: "Is this purchase driven by genuine need, or the primal, manufactured fear of loss?"

That pause is your mental clutch engaging.

Understanding this internal dynamic is the first step to mastering your own behaviour and your brand's messaging. An effective brand speaks first to the emotional instinct, then offers the logic the mind needs to justify the action.

posts.hook: The most expensive design mistake in history wasn't a car or a building. It was a carton of orange juice.
posts.cta: What is a rebrand that you absolutely hated?
posts.postBody:
The most expensive design mistake in history wasn't a car or a building. It was a carton of orange juice.

In 2009, Tropicana decided its brand needed a refresh. They scrapped their classic packaging and replaced it with a sleek, modern, "clean" design. They spent $35 million on the rollout.

The result? Sales plummeted 20% in just two months. They lost roughly $30 million in revenue before frantically reverting to the old design.

That is a $65 million lesson in neuroscience.

The marketing team was pitching to the New Brain. They thought the new design looked premium and modern. But they completely ignored the Old Brain.

As I explain in The Divided Brain, the Old Brain is an energy-hoarding machine. It relies on "pattern recognition" to navigate the world quickly. When a shopper walks down the aisle, their Old Brain isn't reading labels. It is scanning for shapes and colours it trusts.

For decades, "Orange with a Straw" equalled "My Juice." It was a mental shortcut. When Tropicana changed the visual cue, they broke the pattern. The Old Brain didn't see "modern." It saw "unfamiliar."

This brings us to the MAYA principle: Most Advanced Yet Acceptable.

To sell something surprising, make it familiar. To sell something familiar, make it surprising.

Don't let your New Brain's desire for creativity destroy your Old Brain's hard-earned equity.

What is a rebrand that you absolutely hated?

posts.hook: Apple hasn't been the same company for forty years. They have actually been four different companies.
posts.cta: Are you still telling your startup story, even though you are now the market leader?
posts.postBody:
I am a huge advocate for brand consistency. You shouldn't change your logo or colours just because you're bored.

But while your visual identity should remain steady, your positioning must evolve as you grow. Just look at Apple.

In my book, The Divided Brain, I break down how they masterfully shifted their Archetype to match their business reality.

The Outlaw (1984): They were the rebels. The hammer thrower in the Super Bowl ad.
The Creator (1990s): The "Think Different" campaign ‚Äî about imagination, not computers.
The Magician (2000s): Steve Jobs put "1,000 songs in your pocket." It wasn't engineering. It was alchemy.
The Ruler (Today): They don't rebel. They rule.

Because Archetypes are the language of the Old Brain. We recognize them instinctively.

If Apple tried to act like the "Outlaw" today, while being a trillion-dollar corporation, your Old Brain would instantly flag it as inauthentic.

Successful brands know that as they grow, their story must grow with them. You can't be the scrappy startup forever. Eventually, you have to put on the crown.

Are you still telling your startup story, even though you are now the market leader?

posts.hook: Giving your customers more options often leads to fewer sales.
posts.cta: How can I remove the friction of choice?
posts.postBody:
Giving your customers more options often leads to fewer sales.

We tend to think that offering more choice is better service. Behavioural science says the opposite is true.

In a famous study I reference in The Divided Brain, researchers set up a tasting booth with jams. When they offered 24 varieties, only 3% of people made a purchase. When they offered just 6 varieties, 30% of people bought a jar.

Why the massive gap?

Your customer's Old Brain is obsessed with conserving energy. It views complexity as a tax on its fuel supply. When faced with too many choices, the Old Brain gets overwhelmed by the fear of making the wrong choice. So it chooses nothing at all.

This is "Analysis Paralysis."

If you want to increase conversions, stop expanding your menu. Curate it.

Start asking: "How can I remove the friction of choice?"

When you simplify the path, you don't just make it easier to buy ‚Äî you make it easier for the brain to say "Yes."

posts.hook: The fastest way to lose a customer is to assume they are being rational.
posts.postBody:
The fastest way to lose a customer is to assume they are being rational, which is a dangerous trap for businesses.

Rationality is usually a convenient story we tell ourselves after the fact to justify an emotionally driven decision.

The Old Brain, focused on survival, looks for safety, certainty, and a sense of belonging in every choice.

The New Brain, responsible for logic and language, looks for detailed explanations to create that narrative of rationality.

Most brands make the critical mistake of talking to the wrong one first, overloading the customer with logic before establishing emotional trust.

posts.topic: Stop Asking Customers / Brand Value Canvas
posts.hook: Stop asking your customers what they want. Most of the time, they are inadvertently lying to you.
posts.cta: Have you ever found yourself making a logical excuse for a purchase you knew was purely emotional?
posts.postBody:
Stop asking your customers what they want.

Most of the time, they are inadvertently lying to you (and to themselves).

I have spent decades watching companies pour millions into focus groups and market research, only to watch the resulting products flop at the cash register.

The reason is simple: you and your customers have what I call a divided brain.

The Big Gear is the Old Brain. Fast, emotional, driven by survival. This is where every single purchase decision is made.

The Small Gear is the New Brain. Logical, slow, and analytical.

Here is the trap: when you ask a customer why they bought a specific product, you are interviewing the New Brain. But the New Brain is not the CEO of the mind. It is the Press Secretary.

Its only job is to provide a logical-sounding explanation for a decision the Old Brain already made based on a gut feeling.

If you ask someone why they bought a luxury watch, they will talk to you about the craftsmanship. In reality, their Old Brain bought it for tribal belonging or social status.

This is why I developed the Brand Value Canvas. A tool designed to bypass the logical noise and map out the Customer Insights that actually trigger the Big Gear.

Stop selling to the explanation. Start selling to the instinct.

Have you ever found yourself making a logical excuse for a purchase you knew was purely emotional?

Most business decisions are not made logically.

They are justified logically after an emotional decision has already been made.

That misunderstanding explains why so many smart strategies fail.

The Old Brain decides fast, emotionally, and defensively.

The New Brain explains later and calls it "rational."

I write about how those two systems collide in branding, leadership, and real business decisions.

posts.hook: Why the best ideas don't always win.
posts.cta: By the time the rational mind catches up, emotion has already cast the vote.
posts.postBody:
Why the best ideas don't always win.

We've all seen it happen. A pitch that's backed by logic, data, and strategy: dead on arrival. Then someone walks in with something simpler, more emotional ‚Äî and the room lights up.

That moment isn't random. It's your Divided Brain at work.

In every conversation, presentation, or campaign, two systems inside us are fighting for control. The Old Brain ‚Äî fast, emotional, instinctive ‚Äî reacts first. The New Brain ‚Äî slow, rational, deliberate ‚Äî tries to make sense of it after the fact.

The problem? We build most business communication for the wrong audience. We talk to the New Brain, assuming logic leads the way. But it doesn't.

In The Divided Brain, I unpack how real decisions are made ‚Äî and how to speak to the emotional gear that actually moves people. Whether you're leading a team, launching a brand, or negotiating a deal, understanding which brain you're talking to changes everything.

It's not manipulation. It's simply working with human nature instead of against it.

By the time the rational mind catches up, emotion has already cast the vote.

posts.hook: Your brain is not looking for the best choice. It is looking for the safest one.
posts.cta: Are you making your customers work too hard to trust you? Or are you giving their Old Brain the anchor it needs to say yes?
posts.postBody:
Your brain is not looking for the best choice. It is looking for the safest one.

When we enter a new marketplace or look at a new product, we think we're being analytical. We're not.

In my book, The Divided Brain, I explain that your customer's Old Brain is an energy-hoarding machine. Its primary mission is survival. When it encounters something "new," its default reaction isn't curiosity; it's a low-level sense of threat.

To lower that threat, the brain scans for patterns it recognizes.

This is why global legacy brands often win over innovative startups. They aren't always the "best" in their category, but they are the most predictable. Predictability equals safety. Safety equals a "Yes" from the Old Brain.

The strategic mistake I see most often in business is trying to be "disruptive" or "different" without first being familiar. If you make your customer work too hard to understand what you do or why you matter, their Old Brain will simply ignore you to save calories.

You haven't failed because of your product; you've failed because you triggered a "threat" signal by being too unfamiliar.

The Strategy: To sell something new, make it look familiar. To sell something familiar, make it look new.

Are you making your customers work too hard to trust you? Or are you giving their Old Brain the anchor it needs to say yes?

posts.hook: In the 90s, we worked with a guy named Ted.
posts.cta: What is the Banita story for your brand?
posts.postBody:
In the 90s, we worked with a guy named Ted. He had just opened his own auto repair shop and, like most business owners, he wanted to fill his ads with facts.

My team and I pushed back. We knew that facts speak to the New Brain. But trust? Trust lives in the Old Brain.

So we took a different route. We ran a campaign featuring his wife, Banita. The entire premise was that she complained Ted was always too busy fixing customers' cars to fix hers.

The tagline became legendary in town: "We fix anyone's car, except Banita's!"

It wasn't about horsepower or oil changes. It was a story about character. It signalled selflessness and dedication ‚Äî traits the emotional Old Brain craves when looking for a provider.

The result? Ted's business grew from three service bays to twenty. The campaign ran for two decades.

If we had led with the "rational" argument ‚Äî prices and equipment ‚Äî Ted would have been just another mechanic. By leading with the emotional story, he became a neighbour you could trust.

In The Divided Brain, I discuss how the Old Brain is the gatekeeper. If you bore the gatekeeper with facts before you've earned its trust with emotion, you never even get in the door.

What is the "Banita" story for your brand?

posts.hook: Why the Brain Craves Resolution.
posts.postBody:
Why the Brain Craves Resolution

One of the strongest drivers of human behaviour is the need to close the loop. When something feels unfinished, the Old Brain treats it as a problem that must be solved. It pulls our attention back, keeps us thinking about it, and makes it difficult to move on.

In business, this shows up everywhere. A client who goes quiet after a proposal may not be undecided at all. They may simply feel the loop is still open. They need a clear path forward before they can commit.

The New Brain can analyze, question, and explore possibilities, but it is the Old Brain that determines when something feels complete. When you offer a next step, a timeline, or a clear expectation, the emotional tension drops. People shift from uncertainty to momentum because the brain finally has closure.

Leaders and brands who recognize this design better conversations. They remove guesswork. They give people a sense of progress. They help decisions move forward by satisfying one of the brain's most fundamental needs.

It is not about pressure. It is about creating clarity that allows both parts of the brain to work together.

posts.hook: Why the Brain Hates Uncertainty
posts.postBody:
Why the Brain Hates Uncertainty

When people hesitate, stall, or "need to think about it," it is rarely about price or product. It is almost always about uncertainty.

The Old Brain's primary job is survival, and uncertainty feels like risk. When the brain senses risk, it hesitates. It asks for more information, delays decisions, and clings to the familiar.

The New Brain may enjoy exploring possibilities, but it is the Old Brain that makes the final call. Before it agrees, it needs to feel safe. It looks for signals of trust, consistency, and confidence.

You can see this in almost every area of business. People buy from brands they recognize. Investors back founders who sound certain. Teams follow leaders who make complex plans sound simple.

When decisions stall, it is not usually logic that has failed. It is emotion that has not been settled. Once you resolve that uncertainty through clarity, trust, and reassurance, momentum returns.

posts.hook: Years ago, I witnessed a client reject a demonstrably superior business proposal in favour of a markedly weaker one.
posts.cta: Have you ever witnessed this before? I'd love to hear about your story in the comments.
posts.postBody:
Years ago, I witnessed a pivotal moment where a client made a baffling choice, ultimately rejecting a demonstrably superior business proposal in favour of a markedly weaker one.

The failure was not one of rational argument; it was one of psychological resonance.

The stronger pitch was meticulously constructed to appeal exclusively to the New Brain ‚Äî the rational, analytical, and logical part. While the logic was sound, it arrived too late. The client's Old Brain was already experiencing discomfort, uneasiness, or a subconscious threat response.

By the time the analytical arguments were processed, the critical decision had already been finalized on a deeply visceral, non-rational level.

This quiet, pre-cognitive death is the way most failed deals and lost opportunities perish. They don't die from a lack of facts or figures; they die from a failure to address foundational trust, safety, and emotional alignment first.

Grasping this distinction ‚Äî that the decision-making process is led by the Old Brain and merely ratified by the New Brain ‚Äî demands a complete paradigm shift in how you approach:

Selling: Address primal fears and establish trust before deploying complex data.
Leading: Appeal to your team's sense of purpose and security before introducing strategic complexities.
Persuasion: Engage the emotional core before attempting to sway opinion with advanced logic.

Have you ever witnessed this before? I'd love to hear about your story in the comments.

posts.hook: Your customers are not trying to win. They are trying not to lose.
posts.cta: What is your customer currently losing by not working with you?
posts.postBody:
Your customers are not trying to win. They are trying not to lose.

This is one of the most misunderstood principles in branding and sales.

We assume people are motivated by gains. Better features. More benefits. Higher returns. So we build our entire pitch around what they stand to gain.

But behavioural science tells us something different. Losses are felt roughly twice as intensely as equivalent gains. Losing $100 stings far more than finding $100 feels good.

This is Loss Aversion, and the Old Brain is obsessed with it.

From a survival perspective, this makes perfect sense. Our ancestors, who were paranoid about losing resources, lived longer than the optimists who chased every opportunity.

In business, this shows up constantly. Customers cling to their current provider even when a competitor offers something better. The fear of making a wrong switch outweighs the potential upside.

The strategic shift is simple: stop selling what they will gain. Start showing what they are currently losing.

Instead of "Our software will increase your efficiency by 20%," try "You are losing 20% of your team's time to manual processes every week."

The first appeals to the New Brain. It sounds nice. The second activates the Old Brain. It demands action.

What is your customer currently losing by not working with you?

posts.hook: Nobody wants to be first. Everybody wants to be next.
posts.cta: Where is the tribal proof in your brand?
posts.postBody:
Nobody wants to be first. Everybody wants to be next.

This is one of the Old Brain's most powerful programs: follow the tribe.

For hundreds of thousands of years, survival meant staying with the group. The loner who wandered off to try something new usually did not live long enough to pass on their genes. The ones who watched what others did and then followed thrived.

That instinct did not disappear when we moved into offices and online shopping carts. It just found new expressions.

Reviews. Testimonials. "Join 10,000 customers." "As seen in Forbes."

These are not just marketing tactics. They are tribal signals. They tell the Old Brain, "Others like you have done this and survived. It is safe to proceed."

This is Social Proof, and it bypasses logic entirely.

The New Brain might analyze features and compare prices. But the Old Brain is scanning for a different kind of data: "What are people like me doing?"

This is why an empty restaurant struggles to fill seats while the crowded one has a waiting list. Why a product with thousands of reviews outsells a superior one with twelve. Why "bestseller" is one of the most powerful words in marketing.

We think we make independent decisions. We do not. We make tribal ones, then tell ourselves a story about why we were being rational.

The strategic question for any brand is not just "Why should they buy?" It is "Who else like them has already bought, and how do we make that visible?"

In The Divided Brain, I explore how belonging is not a nice-to-have. It is a survival need that the Old Brain treats with the same urgency as food and shelter.

When you activate that instinct, you are no longer selling. You are inviting someone into a group they already want to join.

Where is the tribal proof in your brand?

posts.hook: Your customer decides if they trust you before they hear a word you say.
posts.cta: What is creating your halo? And more importantly, what might be breaking it?
posts.postBody:
Your customer decides if they trust you before they hear a word you say.

This is the Halo Effect in action.

When the Old Brain encounters something it likes ‚Äî an attractive design, a familiar face, a confident first impression ‚Äî it assumes everything else must be equally good.

This is why Apple can charge a premium for a cable. Why a well-dressed founder gets funded faster. Why a beautifully designed website converts better, even if the product is identical to a competitor's.

Here is the trap for businesses: we spend enormous energy perfecting our core offering while neglecting the "superficial" signals. But to the Old Brain, there is no such thing as superficial. Everything is data.

The font on your invoice. The design of your proposal deck. Whether your Zoom background looks professional or chaotic. The typo in your follow-up email. Whether your LinkedIn profile photo looks like it was taken this decade.

Each touchpoint either reinforces the halo or cracks it.

The brands that win are not always the ones with the best product. They are the ones who first earned the halo.

What is creating your halo? And more importantly, what might be breaking it?

posts.hook: Stop trying to be different. Start being familiar.
posts.cta: Are you being too different? Or not different enough?
posts.postBody:
Stop trying to be different. Start being familiar.

There is a principle in design called MAYA ‚Äî Most Advanced, Yet Acceptable ‚Äî coined by the legendary industrial designer Raymond Loewy.

Your customers' brains aren't looking for the newest, flashiest thing. They are hardwired to seek safety in what they already know.

Think of your Old Brain as a gatekeeper. Its primary job isn't to innovate ‚Äî it's to survive. Every new stimulus is filtered through a simple question: 'Is this safe?'

When you introduce something truly new, the brain sees it as a potential threat. But when you present something different that fits an existing pattern, the brain gets excited. It sees novelty and safety.

This is why Apple didn't sell computers. They sold '1984' and 'Think Different.' They aligned with a deep cultural archetype (the Rebel) that felt simultaneously fresh and familiar. The computer was just the vehicle.

The magic spot for any brand is familiar enough to trust, different enough to notice.

The lesson? Don't reinvent the wheel. Evolve it.

Are you being too different? Or not different enough?
